facts.text: Twenty-one appeals arise from the judgment of the Assam High Court: eleven by special leave and ten on certificates granted by the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: These twenty-one appeals  eleven by special leave and ten on certificates granted by the High Court  arise from the judgment of the Assam High Court and will be dealt with together, as they raise companymon questions.

facts.text: Assam High Court delivered judgment and order dated September 9, 1964 in Civil Rules Nos. 115, 128, 134, 136, 151, 161, 197 and 160 of 1963.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgement and order dated September 9, 1964 of the Assam and Nagaland High Court in Civil Rules Nos. 115, 128, 134, 136, 151, 161, 197 and 160 of 1963.

facts.text: Assam Legislature passed Assam Primary Education Act, No. XIII of 1947 in the year 1947.

anchor.surface_text: In the year 1947 the Assam Legislature passed an Act known as the Assam Primary Education Act, No. XIII of 1947, in order to provide for development of primary education in the State.

facts.text: Assam Primary Education Act, No. XIII of 1947 was repealed by the Assam Basic Education Act, No. XXVI of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: That Act was repealed by the Assam Basic Education Act, No. XXVI of 1954  hereinafter referred to as the 1954- Act  which was passed to provide for development, expansion, management and companytrol of basic education

facts.text: Assam Basic Education Act, No. XXVI of 1954 was repealed by the Assam Elementary Education Act, No. XXX of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: The 1954-Act was repealed by the Assam Elementary Education Act, No. XXX of 1962,  hereinafter referred to as the Act .

facts.text: Assam Elementary Education Act, No. XXX of 1962 came into force from October 5, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: The Act was to companye into force at once and it actually came into force from October 5, 1962.

facts.text: School Boards functioning under the 1954-Act were abolished by the 1962 Act.

anchor.surface_text: The main change in the Act was that the School Boards func- tioning under the 1954-Act were abolished and in their place the Deputy Inspectors of Schools,

facts.text: Deputy Inspectors of Schools were made Assistant Secretaries of the State Board with the same headquarters and jurisdiction.

anchor.surface_text: and in their place the Deputy Inspectors of Schools, by virtue of their office, were made Assistant Secretaries of the State Board with the same headquarter and jurisdiction as they had as Deputy Inspectors of Schools.

facts.text: State Advisory Board passed a resolution on November 20, 1962 to discharge all teachers who are non-matriculates or who have not passed the Teachers Test with effect from 31-3-1963.

anchor.surface_text: On November 20, 1962, the State Advisory Board passed a- resolution, the relevant part of which is in these terms- Subject to the exceptions enumerated below, all teachers who are number matriculates or who have number passed the Teachers Test but who are working as teachers in. schools shall be discharged with effect from 31-3-1963.

facts.text: Secretary to the State Advisory Board wrote a letter to all Secretaries, School Boards incorporating the resolution of November 20, 1962.

anchor.surface_text: in pursuance of this resolution, the Secretary to the State Advisory Board wrote a letter to all the Secretaries, School Boards, who were numberother than the Deputy Inspectors of Schools and who became Assistant Secretaries of the State Board under s. 14 of the Act.

facts.text: Letter issued to Kripanath Sarma on April 9, 1963 terminating his service with immediate effect under departmental instructions regarding removal of under-matric and non-T.T. teachers.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that after March 31, 1963, action began to be taken on these instructions and a letter was issued to Kripanath Sarma on April 9, 1963 , the relevant part of which is in these terms- Under Departmental Instructions regarding removal of under-matric and number-T.T. Teachers,

facts.text: Similar termination letters issued to other respondent teachers in some cases in May 1963, one in August 1963, and a few in September 1963.

anchor.surface_text: We may add that similar letters were addressed to other teachers who are respondents in the present appeal, though they were addressed in some cases in May 1963 and in one case as late as August 1963. In a few cases letters of removal were addressed to some of the respondents in the present appeals as late as September 1963.

facts.text: No termination letter was addressed to any teacher before March 31, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: But it is remarkable that numberletter was addressed to anyone before March 3 1, 1963 intimating that his service would be terminated from March 31, 1963.

facts.text: Writ petitions filed in the High Court challenging the orders of termination of services of respondent teachers.

anchor.surface_text: On termination of the services of teachers who are number res- pondents in these appeals before us, a number of writ petitions were filed in the High Court challenging the orders of termination.

facts.text: High Court allowed the writ petitions and set aside the orders terminating services of the respondents.

anchor.surface_text: In companysequence the petitions were allowed and the orders terminating the services of the respondents were set aside.

facts.text: Appellants came to Supreme Court in some cases on certificates from High Court and in others on special leave.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon the appellants came to this Court in some cases on certificates obtained from the High Court and in others on special leave obtained from this Court.

facts.text: Teachers taken over by State Board under Section 34(2) with emoluments and seniority protected.

anchor.surface_text: Section 34 2  of the Act provides that as soon as it came into force all teachers and other employees of schools maintained by School Boards would be taken over by the State Board subject to the companydition that the total emoluments of the employees at the time they were taken over would be protected and their seniority would be maintained.

facts.text: All existing teachers deemed employed by State Board under Section 38.

anchor.surface_text: Section 38 provides that- all teachers existing or to be appointed in any Elementary School recognised under the Act, except in the case of the A utonomous Districts, shall be deemed to have been employed by the State Board.

facts.text: State Advisory Board continued after October 5, 1962 until State Board constituted.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that by virtue of this provision the State Advisory Board companytinued even after October 5, 1962, as apparently it took sometime to companystitute the State Board under the Act.

facts.text: No services of any single teacher ended on March 31, 1963; termination letters began from April 9, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: It is also remarkable that services of number a single teacher came to an end on March 31, 1963.The letters intimating to the teachers that their services were terminated began from April 9, 1963 and companytinued upto some date in September 1963.

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals with costs.

anchor.surface_text: The appeals therefore fail and are hereby dismissed with companyts, one hearing fee.

facts.text: Resolution of November 20, 1962 was not communicated to any teacher.

anchor.surface_text: It is number in dispute that this resolution was number companymunicated to any teacher as such and obviously it companyld number be companymunicated to any teacher who might even be governed by its terms
Appeals by special leave from the judgement and order dated September 9, 1964 of the Assam and Nagaland High Court in Civil Rules Nos. 115, 128, 134, 136, 151, 161, 197 and 160 of 1963.
On termination of the services of teachers who are number res- pondents in these appeals before us, a number of writ petitions were filed in the High Court challenging the orders of termination.
termination of their services was in violation of the provision of Art. 311 2  of the Constitution. These petitions were opposed on behalf of the State and in some cases by the State Board.

anchor.surface_text: Section 3 of the Act provides for the constitution of a State Board for Elementary Education  hereinafter referred to as the State Board  and the State Board was made a companyporate body with perpetual succession and a companymon seal.

The functions of the State Board were defined in s. 10 which inter alia provides that the State Board shall lay down principles for allocation of grants for carrying out the purposes of the Act to local authorities,

issues.text: Whether the Deputy Inspector of Schools, in his capacity as the Assistant Secretary of the State Board, could terminate the services of the respondents in view of s.14(3)(iii) of the Act read with s.18 of the 1915-Act.

anchor.surface_text: We shall first consider whether the Deputy Inspector of Schools,in his capacity as the Assistant Secretary of the State Board, could terminate the services of the respondents in view of s. 14 3 iii of the Act read with s. 18 of the 1915-Act.

issues.text: Whether s.55(2) deems appointments under the 1954-Act by School Boards to have been made by the Assistant Secretary under s.14(3)(iii), thereby giving him power to terminate.

anchor.surface_text: Reading therefore s. 34 2 and s. 38 together, the conclusion is inevitable that there is no occasion for the application of the deeming provision in s. 55 in the case of these teachers.

issues.text: Whether the respondents have been dismissed by the State Board.

anchor.surface_text: This brings us to the alternative argument, namely, whether the respondents have been dismissed by the State Board.

issues.text: Whether the resolution dated November 20, 1962 of the State Advisory Board amounts to an order terminating the services of the teachers or merely lays down policy principles.

anchor.surface_text: The question that arises therefore is whether the said resolution can be said to have terminated the service of anyone at all.

issues.text: Whether the respondent-teachers were holding civil posts under the State and termination of their services was in violation of Art. 311(2) of the Constitution.

anchor.surface_text: the respondent-teachers were holding civil posts under the State and termination of their services was in violation of the provision of Art. 311 2 of the Constitution.

holdings.text: The Assistant Secretary could not terminate the services of the respondent-teachers under s.14(3)(iii) read with s.18 of the 1915-Act as they were not appointed by him.

anchor.surface_text: We are therefore in agreement with the High Court, though for slightly different reasons, that the services of the respondent-teachers could not be terminated by the Assistant Secretary of the State Board under s. 14 3   iii  of the Act read with s.18 of the 1915-Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Pre-1962 teachers appointed by School Boards, not by Assistant Secretary created by 1962 Act; s.18 GCA only empowers dismissal of those appointed by the authority.

holdings.text: s.55(2) does not deem pre-Act appointments by School Boards to have been made by Assistant Secretary under s.14(3)(iii).

anchor.surface_text: Reading therefore s. 34 2  and s. 38 together, the conclusion is inevitable that there is no occasion for the application of the deeming provision in s. 55 in the case of these teachers. In the face of these two specific provisions the general deeming provision contained in s. 55 2  cannot be used

holdings.reasoning_summary: Specific provisions in ss.34(2) and 38 for takeover and deeming employment by State Board prevail over general deeming in s.55(2).

holdings.text: The respondents were not dismissed by the State Board.

anchor.surface_text: This brings us to the alternative argument, namely, whether the respondents have been dismissed by the State Board.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Termination orders were by Assistant Secretary without authority; no valid action by State Board.

holdings.text: The resolution dated November 20, 1962 does not amount to termination of services but lays down policy principles.

anchor.surface_text: The question that arises therefore is whether the said resolution can be said to have terminated the service of anyone at all. It certainly begins by saying that all teachers who are non matriculates

holdings.reasoning_summary: Resolution general, names unknown, not communicated to teachers; cites Bachittar Singh requiring communication; subsequent letters show no termination on 31-3-1963.

holdings.text: The resolution does not amount to delegation of termination authority.

anchor.surface_text: Then it is urged that the resolution may be taken to amount to a delegation by the State Board of its authority to terminate services of teachers after laying down principles for such termination. We consider that there is no force in this contention either.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No express words of delegation; unclear to whom; delegation if any must be by State Board resolution, not implied.

holdings.text: Power to appoint under s.14(3)(iii) includes power to dismiss under s.18 GCA despite requirement of advice from committee.

anchor.surface_text: Now as we read S. 14 3 iii of the Act, it is obvious that the power of appointment is only in the Assistant Secretary, though that power has to be exercised on the advice of the Committee constituted under s. 16

holdings.reasoning_summary: Appointing authority remains Assistant Secretary; advice does not create 'different intention' under s.18 excluding dismissal power.

holdings.text: State Board as employer has power under general master-servant law to terminate services unless circumscribed by statute.

anchor.surface_text: There is no doubt that reading s. 34 2  and s. 38 together, the existing teachers were taken over by the State Board and became its employees. Therefore, as their employer, the State Board would have power under the general law of master and servant

holdings.reasoning_summary: Employees of State Board post-takeover; general law applies absent statutory bar.
